journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Time-delay compensation for actuator-based hardware-in-the-loop testing of a jet engine fuel control unit

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Islamic Republic of Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mostafa Nasiri, Systems Simulation and Control Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak, Tehran 16846-13114, Islamic Republic of Iran. Email: m_nasiri@iust.ac.ir

abstract.p: Actuator-based hardware-in-the-loop is a form of hardware-in-the-loop testing where the hardware components are mechanical systems. Hardware-in-the-loop testing of mechanical components requires an additional transfer system which typically comprises sensors and actuators to link the software and hardware. Inaccuracy and instability can occur during actuator-based hardware-in-the-loop testing if the time delay due to the transfer system dynamics is not properly compensated for. This paper presents a new application of the Smith predictor strategy for hardware-in-the-loop testing of an electro-hydraulic fuel control unit for a turbojet engine. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the method for time-delay compensation of actuator-based hardware-in-the-loop testing.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) simulation enables the operation and testing of actual components of a system along with a virtual computer-based simulation of the rest of the system in real time.1 In a typical HIL test, the hardware component consists of a box of electronic components which can communicate with the software models via electrical signals exchanged using a data acquisition card. Several studies have reported use of the HIL simulation approach for rapid prototyping of the electronic control unit (ECU) of jet engines.2–4

Recently, the use of HIL simulation to test mechanical and other components has been an area of interest. Such applications that have significant power flows between the real hardware and the simulation make their design more challenging. This kind of HIL simulation is often called actuator-based HIL (Ab-HIL) simulation.5 In the field of aerospace engineering, several research works have been undertaken to employ the concept of HIL simulation to examine the performance of aircraft vehicle mechanical components within a closed-loop virtual simulation of the remaining subsystems.6–8

The main difficulty in Ab-HIL testing is that connecting a mechanical component to a software model requires additional dynamic transfer systems. The transfer systems typically comprise sensors and actuators and the dynamic effects of these additional systems need to be mitigated to achieve more accurate results. In many cases, the dynamics of the transfer system can be assumed as a pure time delay. Several approaches have been suggested to compensate for a pure delay including polynomial extrapolation,9,10 Smith predictor,11 emulator-based control,12 linear acceleration extrapolation,13 derivative feedforward compensation14 and the inverse compensation method.15 These methods have been considered for civil engineering systems with the topic of real-time dynamic substructuring (RTDS). Recently, the present authors16 reported the Ab-HIL testing of a fuel control unit (FCU) for a turbojet engine. The results were achieved with reduced ECU gains to maintain stability regardless of time-delay effects.

In the present paper, Ab-HIL testing is accomplished with the same test stand as in our previous work16 but with a well-tuned ECU for which time delay of the transfer system causes the system to be unstable. In this application, use of the Smith predictor strategy is proposed for time-delay compensation of the Ab-HIL testing. According to test results, the Smith-based time-delay compensator gives an effective solution to the problem of stability and fidelity caused by the time delay arising from an unwanted flowmeter sensor. This method has the disadvantage of requiring an accurate model of the physical system but the advantage of not distorting the nominal closed-loop system.

This work is a part of a study aimed at testing an online parameter estimator. The analytical model of the electro-hydraulic FCU with uncertain parameters that may possibly vary with time is considered to be identified. For example, the bulk modulus is dependent on pressure and temperature. Likewise, fluid density, damping coefficients and other parameters of the model are uncertain and dependent on operating conditions. For this reason, a model-based online parameter identification scheme is developed for the FCU. The designed parameter estimator should show good following of unknown parameters in real conditions even with the presence of sensor noises. Moreover, the estimation algorithm does not run in real time if the algorithm is computationally too complex. The real measurement noises of the sensors together with the real-time characteristic of HIL simulation make the Ab-HIL test bench a suitable framework for testing of an online parameter estimator.

sec.title: Actuator-based hardware-in-the-loop simulation
sec.p: Ab-HIL simulation involves having a model in two parts, one to be tested as a hardware component and one to be implemented as a software model. The software subsystem is connected to the hardware subsystem via a computer digital-to-analog interface driving a physical actuator; the connection is referred to as the transfer system. Gawthrop et al.12 showed how Ab-HIL can be viewed as a feedback system, represented in conventional block diagram form in Figure 1, where P is the hardware component, N represents the software model and T is the transfer system.

caption.p: Actuator-based hardware-in-the-loop simulation.

sec.p: The Ab-HIL concept differs in that the hardware is a mechanical system, not an electronic controller. Thus, the real-time simulation in an Ab-HIL system interfaces with the rest of the system using actuators and sensors. Sensors and actuators have their own dynamic characteristics, they are affected by noise and disturbances, and the actuator response is dependent on the behavior of the attached physical system. In this application, the transfer system may be approximated to a pure time delay, e−τs, for a certain range of frequencies, or a first-order lag, 1/(τs+1). Both models of transfer system for the delay and the lag have the same first-order Taylor expansion of (1−τs). As a result, there is not much practical difference between the approaches in the case of small delays. The delays in the transfer system can have highly destabilizing effects, especially for systems with very light damping. This is due to the fact that delay can act as a form of negative damping, reducing the combined system damping to zero and therefore producing instability. In the ideal situation, the transfer function of the transfer system T(s)=1, so that the software model output matches the hardware component input exactly.

sec.title: Time-delay compensation strategies
sec.p: The object of time-delay compensation is to design a strategy to eliminate or at least mitigate the unwanted effects of the transfer system from the closed-loop system. In some cases, the dynamics of the transfer system can be removed from the closed-loop system by using an inverted model of the transfer system dynamics, if the transfer system is casually invertible. One of the most commonly considered examples of a non-invertible transfer system is that of a pure time delay. A number of approaches have been suggested to compensate for a pure time delay including polynomial extrapolation, adaptive forward prediction and Smith predictor. These methods have been studied in the context of RTDS in the field of civil engineering.

In the application of Ab-HIL testing, the Smith predictor—unlike the other approaches—has the property of not deforming the nominal closed-loop system. Comparison of Figure 2(a) and (b) illustrates how the Smith predictor maintains the original closed-loop system. In the Ab-HIL testing, the object of time-delay compensation is not to design a controller to remove the effect of time delay in the plant; the objective is to mitigate the effect of additional dynamic or transfer systems from the closed-loop system without changing the original designed controller. Hereby, the non-distorting advantage of the Smith predictor makes it suitable to use for Ab-HIL testing.

caption.p: (a) Block diagram of the closed-loop system without time delay; (b) block diagram of the closed-loop system with time delay and Smith predictor.

sec.title: Smith predictor
sec.p: Smith proposed a method of time-delay compensation by comparing the transfer functions of closed-loop systems with and without time delay. The closed-loop transfer function for the control system without time delay shown in Figure 2(a) can be obtained as11

where Y is the output, R is the reference input, C and G are the controller and plant transfer functions respectively. Now suppose a compensator G¯(s)is designed for the time-delay system. The closed-loop transfer function for time delay system can be obtained as
Equating M*(s) to M(s)e-τs, one obtains

The physical representation of the compensator in equation (3) is shown in Figure 2(b). It is observed from linear model transfer functions that the characteristic equation of the delayed system with Smith predictor is the same as that of the ideal system. Hence, stability using the Smith predictor is always guaranteed.
Figure 3 is a diagram of the Smith predictor control scheme which may possibly be more convenient for practical use.

caption.p: Diagram of the practical Smith predictor.

sec.p: The Smith approach, unlike the other methods, has the disadvantage of requiring an accurate model of the physical system’s transfer function but the advantage of not distorting the original closed-loop control system.

In the well-tuned ECU in which gains are adjusted to achieve a desired performance, the ECU gains are high and the additional time delay in the control loop causes the system to be unstable. Therefore, if a time delay is introduced into a control loop with high gains, the gains must be reduced to maintain stability or have a time-delay compensator to mitigate the effects of time delay. In primary tests, the ECU gains were reduced in order to have stability in spite of time delay in the control loop of the HIL test. The Smith predictor control scheme can help overcome this limitation and allow larger ECU gains.

sec.title: Fuel control unit
sec.p: Basic components of the proposed electro-hydraulic fuel control system are shown in Figure 4. A gear-type fuel pump, which is driven in a fraction of the engine shaft speed, supplies fuel to the system. The unit employs a pressure balanced metering valve, which consists of a plunger and a barrel with longitudinal slits, to control fuel flow rate. Depending on the position of the plunger exposing the slits in the barrel and with the assurance of constant differential pressure, the fuel flow rate to the engine is proportional to the flow area. The spool-type bypass valve is used to keep the differential pressure across the metering valve constant by spilling back the excess fuel flow delivered by the pump to the tank. This causes the metering valve operation to become linear with respect to the flow area. A servo motor is employed to operate on the metering valve plunger and a screw is used to convert the servo motor’s rotational motion to linear movement. Also a spring maintains the connection between the barrel and shaft during retraction. A restriction orifice is used to prevent bypass valve spool fluctuation by the eventual pump flow impulses. Finally, the fuel nozzle is connected at the output part of the FCU.

caption.p: The fuel control unit.

sec.p: As stated in the previous section, the Smith predictor requires having an accurate model of the physical system. In this research, the Wiener approach is employed for modeling the dynamic behavior of the FCU. As shown in Figure 5, the Wiener model is one of the block structure systems, which consists of a linear dynamic element in series with a static nonlinear part. The nonlinearity in Wiener models is caused by the variation of the system static and dynamic characteristics due to the input amplitude.

caption.p: Wiener model of the fuel control unit.

sec.p: Figure 6 shows the static nonlinear part of the Wiener model of the FCU which is driven using experimental results. The linear dynamic element is also proposed as a first-order transfer function, 1/(τs+1), with τ=0.2s.

caption.p: Static nonlinear part of the Wiener model of the fuel control unit.

sec.title: Test stand description
sec.p: A schematic of the hydraulic circuit implemented on the hydraulic test bench for testing the FCU is shown in Figure 7.

caption.p: Hydraulic circuit of the test bench. 1: booster pump; 2,3: pressure sensors; 4: flowmeter; 5: nozzle.

sec.p: The FCU comprises a servomotor and a spool valve as a control block and a miniature gear-type fuel pump as a hydraulic block. As shown in Figure 7, a booster pump sucks the fluid from the atmospheric reservoir and pumps it to the FCU. The controlled flow after the FCU is directed to the nozzle. Fluid pressure in the entrance of the FCU and nozzle are measured and recorded by pressure sensors. In this test stand, the fluid flow rate is measured using a flowmeter. A kind of white oil which is safe and non-flammable, with viscosity and density similar to those of real fuel, is used for the tests. A photograph of the HIL test facility and an overview of the HIL simulator architecture are shown in Figure 8.

caption.p: Laboratory test stand.
(1: host personal computer; 2: target personal computer; 3: convertors; 4: flowmeter; 5: alternating current motor; 6: fuel control unit; 7: servo motor; 8: tank, 9: booster pump; 10: inverter).

sec.title: Integrated framework for fuel control unit testing
sec.p: The integrated framework shown in Figure 9 provides an environment for testing the actual electro-hydraulic FCU in near real conditions. An industrial personal computer (PC) equipped with an ISA card (Advantech PCL-812PG) is employed as a target computer for numerical simulation of the turbojet engine and controlling the speed of the alternating current (AC) motor. The algorithm of the ECU is also implemented on the target PC. Two analog output channels of the data acquisition card are used for exporting the servo motor and AC motor control signals. The servo angle value is a 0–5 V signal that is converted to a pulse-width modulation (PWM) signal using the voltage-to-PWM converter. The PWM signal can be used for driving the servo motor of the FCU. The AC motor control signal is generated according to the AC motor’s speed which is measured using a tachometer. A conventional proportional–integral (PI) controller which is implemented on the target PC is used to control the AC motor’s rotating speed. The analog input channels of the PCL-812PG card are employed to record the signals of the tachometer and flowmeter.

caption.p: Hardware-in-the-loop simulation framework.

sec.title: Additional transfer systems
sec.p: In order to test mechanical components, an additional transfer system is required to link the software and hardware subsystems. In this experiment, as shown in Figure 10, the AC motor and the flowmeter are the additional systems that do not exist in the real system. The AC motor is employed as a speed emulator to drive the pump of the FCU while in the real system a gearbox is used to drive the pump directly from the engine shaft. The flowmeter is also an additional system that is used for measuring the fuel flow rate. According to extensive experimental works, the AC motor’s lag dynamics has no considerable effect on the HIL testing. Therefore, the flowmeter is the only additional transfer system of which the dynamic effect needs to be mitigated. Moreover, the test stand tubing and piping system is different from the real engine, and cause a little time delay in measuring the fuel flow rate.

caption.p: The transfer system.

sec.p: In the studied case, the jet engine is controlled by an ECU, containing some limitation loops and a low-pass filter 1/(τs+1) with τ=0.1s, to avoid or limit surge and stall phenomena within operating range. Consequently, the high frequency inputs are prevented by the ECU to exert upon the FCU. Thereby, the time delay mainly depends on the operating conditions of the turbojet engine. In the HIL testing of the FCU, the mean value of the time delay in different operating conditions is employed as a constant time delay in the Smith predictor.

The transfer system may be approximated to a pure time delay for a certain range of frequencies. A Bode diagram of the system response without delay compensation facilitates the identification of such a range. To measure the frequency response experimentally, the valve position is excited sinusoidally at ±5° amplitude about a nominal valve position of 100° and the fuel flow rate is measured as the output. Based on the test results, the gain and phase angle versus frequency are plotted as shown in Figure 11(a) and (b). The constant time delay can be assumed over a specific frequency range where the slope of the phase curve does not change significantly. In this case, the multi-sine input frequencies are taken between 4 and 8 rad/s where the time delay does not change considerably as shown in Figure 11(c).

caption.p: Bode diagram for the transfer system: (a) magnitude; (b) phase; (c) time delay.

sec.p: The value of the time delay depends on the operating condition. The mean value of the time delay in different operating conditions is used in the predictor. Experimental results show that the mean value of the time delay arising from measuring flow in the HIL testing is about τ=0.3 s. This time delay causes the system to be unstable and should be compensated. The time delay was assumed to be constant in the Smith predictor. In the future studies, an online optimization method will be employed to update the time delay as the experiment runs.

sec.title: Turbojet engine model
sec.p: The HIL testing of the FCU is done within real-time simulation of the single-spool turbojet engine model of Montazeri-Gh et al.,4 with the following nonlinear differential equations
where Tb=(T3+T4)/2, Tn=(T5+Te)/2, Pb=(P3+ P4)/2, Pn=(P5+Pe)/2 and the other parameters are defined in Table 1; a schematic of the turbojet engine is given in Figure 12.

caption.p: Definition of symbols for parameters of the jet engine model.

tr.td: Specific heat of hot/cold air at constant pressure
Ratio of specific heats for hot/cold air

caption.p: The turbojet engine.

sec.p: Moreover, the model also includes the following algebraic equations which, together with the differential equations (4) to (8) above, make up a system of differential and algebraic equations.
Compressor
Turbine
Nozzle

The input of the system is fuel flow m·f and the output measurements are N, P3 and T4. Since the rotor speed of the engine N is used as a command for thrust modulation in the ECU and the FCU corresponds to the engine rotor speed, only the rotor speed is required for delay compensation. The other outputs, P3 and T4, can be employed for limiting considerations in the ECU.

sec.title: Time-delay margin
sec.p: The phase margin ϕφm provides a measure of how near the system is to instability. As the phase margin decreases, the system gets closer to the instability boundary, and therefore the phase margin gives an indication of how robust the system is. In the case when the transfer system dynamics comprises a pure delay e−τs, then the critical delay τc is the time delay which would give a phase lag φm, and is given by

where ωc denotes critical frequency. By plotting the Bode diagram, it is possible to estimate the phase margin in the emulated system. As the Bode diagram uses decibels, |G(jω)|=1 corresponds to the amplitude curve crossing the 0 db gain line and the critical frequency ωc can be found. The corresponding phase margin is found by measuring the difference between the phase curve and −180° at each critical frequency. The phase margin relates directly to the maximum allowable time delay before the system becomes unstable.

To estimate the time-delay margin a linear model of the system is required, so the jet engine nonlinear equations are linearized numerically and put into state space form. The partial derivatives of each state derivative function with respect to every state are numerically approximated. The approximations are taken about the operating point in which the values of all states and inputs are known. For this system, the state space linearized fifth-order model is derived by using the state vector as

Assuming the jet engine rotor speed N as an output, the Bode diagram of the system is plotted as shown in Figure 13. According to Figure 13, the maximum phase delay before stability loss is approximately 0.1 s; but according to test results, the time delay of the HIL testing is about τ=0.3 s. As expected, the system becomes unstable for this time delay. Figure 14 verifies this instability by the Nyquist diagram.

caption.p: Bode diagram for calculating the time-delay margin. The upper plot shows amplitude and the lower plot shows phase. The phase margin is the difference in phase between the phase curve and −180° line at the point corresponding to the frequencies that give 0 dB gain. The critical time-delay value is τ=φ/ω=(64.5/11.1)×(π/180)≈0.1s.

Nyquist diagram for the closed-loop system with time delay of τ=0.3s and the system without time delay. For the system with time delay, the diagram encircles the −1 point in clockwise direction and shows the system is unstable.

sec.title: Smith-based time-delay compensation
sec.p: The aim of a delay compensation strategy is to eliminate the effect of transfer system delay from the combined experimental–numerical model. A straightforward compensator was obtained by assuming that the dynamics of the transfer system is approximated by a pure time delay. Marshall17 indicated that it is possible to apply the Smith principle for time-delay compensation using a nonlinear model. The proof of the validity of this extension to a generalized nonlinear model was proved by Tan and Van Cauwenberghe.18 The Smith approach seems to be effective and simple enough to deal with the issue but the time delay should be precisely determined. For pneumatic and hydraulic systems, the delay time could be experimentally determined. According to test results, the time delay of the present system is about τ=0.3s.

In order to employ the Smith predictor in the time-delay compensation of the Ab-HIL testing, it is required that the original arrangement of the Smith predictor is changed. Hence, the controller C in Figure 3 is replaced with the jet engine model and the ECU. Moreover, the plant G is also replaced with the FCU. Therefore, G¯ demonstrates the FCU model. The complete control scheme for HIL testing of the jet engine FCU is shown in Figure 15.

caption.p: Smith predictor for hardware-in-the-loop testing of the fuel control unit.

sec.title: Experimental results and analysis
sec.p: In the jet engine fuel control system, the relative thrust command can be translated into a command change of the jet engine’s rotor speed. Therefore, the pilot lever angle (PLA) is the reference of the jet engine’s rotor speed. In this paper, an experiment is conducted using the test stand described in the section ‘Framework of the hardware-in-the-loop architecture’ and the Smith predictor designed in the section ‘Smith-based time-delay compensation’. The values of the AC motor’s rotating speed and flow rate are measured by the tachometer and flowmeter, and recorded every 100 µs. The results of HIL simulation with a PLA step input are shown in Figure 16. According to the results, HIL simulation results without the compensator are leading to instability because of the time delay arising from the transfer system. Moreover, a multi-sine reference signal (PLA) is constructed as shown in Figure 17 and the tracking performance of the system is investigated using this command. The credibility of the HIL simulation is established by comparing HIL simulation with a full digital simulation or a model-in-the-loop (MIL) simulation. After going through the results, it becomes clear that the compensated HIL simulation results match those of the MIL simulation. The flowmeter noise inevitably is introduced into the Smith prediction output and it is not negligible. This is one of the drawbacks of the Smith predictor. Because the noise corruption is serious, a first-order filter 1/(τs+1) with τ=0.15s is employed to suppress the influence of the noise. It is noticeable that the filter was already included when the time delay was estimated.

caption.p: Step responses of: (a) engine shaft speed; (b) servo angle.
Tracking responses of: (a) engine shaft speed; (b) fuel flow rate; (c) servo angle.

sec.p: A traditional PI controller is used for regulating the rotating speed of the AC motor. The AC motor controller is implemented in the target computer. The controller uses a fraction of the jet engine shaft speed as the reference and the AC motor rotor speed as the output. Figure 18 shows that the controller is successful in forcing the AC motor to follow the desired speed.

caption.p: Alternating current motor: (a) rotor speed (b) control signal.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This paper describes the details of a HIL simulation environment that has been developed to support the research activities on the design and verification of an electro-hydraulic FCU. The simulator is built around a state-of-the-art hydraulic test bench that can experimentally simulate several systems affecting the performance of the FCU. The experimental hardware is employed within the environment of the numerical real-time simulation of a turbojet engine. In the real engine, the pump of the FCU is driven mechanically by a gearbox from the jet engine’s main shaft. In the HIL test, an AC motor is used to emulate the fuel pump driver. The flowmeter is also an additional transfer system that is used for measuring the fuel flow rate. According to extensive experimental works, the AC motor’s lag dynamics has no considerable effect on the HIL testing. Therefore, the flowmeter is the only additional transfer system of which the dynamic effect needs to be mitigated. In this application, the transfer system is approximated to a time delay arising from measuring the fuel flow in HIL testing.

Smith predictor is a well-established controller design method for the system with time delay. In this paper, it has been shown how it can be used for removing the unwanted transfer system dynamics from an Ab-HIL test. The selected compensation method for this application mainly has the advantage of not distorting the original closed-loop control system. The accuracy of the HIL testing is accomplished by simulating the complete system or MIL simulation. It becomes clear that the compensated HIL simulation results match with those of MIL simulation. An area of future work is to use the adaptive Smith predictor for compensating variable time delays.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
